Fig. 1 IR spectra of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TGA curves of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (a) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (b). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Hydrodynamic diameters vs. temperature. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 UV–vis spectra of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM at 25 °C (a) and 35 °C (b), and photo of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM hydrogels at 25 °C (left) and 35 °C (right). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (A) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (B). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 SEM pictures of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (a) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (b). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM pictures of SiO2@Pt (a), SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (b) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (c, d). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Emission spectra of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM at 25 °C (a) and 35 °C (b), and photo of hydrogel under UV light (left: 25 °C and right: 35 °C). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Luminescent lifetime of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Plots of time vs. volume of hydrogen from AB catalyzed by SiO2@Pt (A), SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (B) at different temperatures. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Schematic illustration of catalysts at different temperatures and TEM picture of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM sample prepared at 35 °C (Scar bar: 200 nm). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Reaction time vs. volume of hydrogen from AB catalyzed by SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (a) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (b) in 5th catalytic experiment (25 °C). Fig. 12 Fig. 13 TEM pictures of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (a) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (b) after reusability experiments. Fig. 13 Thermo-controllable dehydrogenation of ammonia borane by luminescent and thermo-responsive catalysts based on SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM Hui Huang Writing - original draft Investigation Jun Wang Supervision Conceptualization Writing - review & editing * Yafei Xu Investigation Rui Xu Investigation Wuke Li Data curation College of Chemistry, Central China Normal University, Wuhan 430079, China College of Chemistry Central China Normal University Wuhan 430079 China College of Chemistry, Central China Normal University, Wuhan 430079, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this paper, a luminescent and thermo-responsive catalyst based on SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM was prepared by incorporating Pt nanoparticles, luminescent material and mesoporous silica with thermo-responsive polymer. The obtained catalyst was characterized by IR, TGA, UV–vis, SEM, TEM, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and luminescence. The hybrid catalyst exhibits “on-off” green luminescence in solution under UV irradiation, which could be observed by eyes. The catalytic results indicate that the dehydrogenation of ammonia borane (AB) catalyzed by SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM is thermo-controllable and switchable. The SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM shows high catalytic activity for the generation of hydrogen at room temperature. However, it exhibits much lower catalytic activity at high temperature. The catalysts exhibit excellent durability because the support and polymer could prevent the aggregation and leaching of Pt nanoparticles during catalysis. The catalytic research offers a new approach to the thermo-controllable application in the generation of hydrogen from AB. Keywords Dehydrogenation Ammonia borane Thermo-responsive Luminescence 1 Introduction The global demand for energy is increasing with the rapid growth of population and development of modern industry. It is a tremendous challenge for researchers to develop effective, green and renewable energy. Hydrogen as a clean and renewable energy carrier has attracted considerable attention in recent years. Hydrogen is the most promising environmentally-friendly energy which could replace fuel and coal consumption in the future. It could be generally used for fuel cell, heating, transportation and electricity generation. However, despite decades of efforts, the chemical hydrogen storage materials are still the most challenging problem for the practical use of hydrogen energy [1–3]. Among the solid hydrogen storage materials, ammonia borane (AB) has attracted considerable interest due to its high hydrogen storage capacity, high stability and solubility in water. The researches showed that ammonia borane could release hydrogen in the presence of catalysts containing noble (Pt, Ru, Pd, Au and Ag) and non-noble metal (Co, Ni, and Cu) [4–14]. However, the controllable release of hydrogen from AB remains one of the great challenges on the path to clean energy. Therefore, it is essential and meaningful to develop multifunctional and smart catalysts to control the release of hydrogen from AB. Recently, smart polymers gained great interest because their physical-chemical properties and structures could change in response to external stimuli such as temperature, pH and light [15,16]. In particular, poly (N-isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAM) is one of most famous thermosensitive polymers which shows a sharp volume phase transition at lower critical solution temperature (LCST, 32 °C). PNIPAM displays the swollen or shrunken state below or above LCST because of the balanced hydrophilic and hydrophobic groups in chains [17]. The thermo-responsive polymers could incorporate with some inorganic composites, resulting in a new class of smart functional materials [18]. In the hybrid materials, the mechanical and chemical stability of stimuli-responsive polymers could be remarkably improved due to the incorporation of inorganic components. Moreover, the inorganic nanomaterial’s optical, catalytic and electrical properties could be adjusted and controlled by stimuli-responsive polymers in response to external stimuli. Therefore, it is significant for us to fabricate the functional catalysts based on PNIPAM/noble metal and investigate their controllable catalytic activity in dehydrogenation of AB. On the other hand, it is sometimes necessary to graft some luminescent materials on these catalysts for the purpose of monitoring catalysts and understanding catalytic mechanism. Among various luminescent materials, rare earth (RE) materials have attracted growing attention due to their sharp and intense emission bands, high quantum efficiency, long lifetimes and high color purity [19]. A luminescent and smart catalyst could be obtained by assembling luminescent rare earth materials with thermo-responsive PNIPAM and noble metal. The multifunctional composites would combine the outstanding advantages of various components, such as thermo-responsive property of polymers, catalytic activity of metal and luminescence characteristic of RE complex. To the knowledge, there is no report on controllable catalytic activity of PNIPAM/Pt/RE composites in the hydrogen generation from AB. In this paper, Pt nanoparticles were encapsulated in mesoporous silica particles, and luminescent RE complex was grafted on the silica particles. Then the hybrid spheres were integrated into PNIPAM network, resulting in a thermo-responsive and luminescent catalyst. The composite catalyst shows the obvious “on–off” green luminescence in solution. Moreover, the catalyst displays the temperature-controlled and switchable catalytic activity in the hydrolytic dehydrogenation of AB. The catalytic reaction could be “turned on” at room temperature and it could be “turned off” at high temperature. The results show that the smart catalyst has promising potential in controlling the generation of hydrogen from AB. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials H2PtCl6·6H2O, N-isopropylacrylamide, isocyanatopropyltriethoxysilane, p-aminobenzoic acid, and AB were obtained from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), Sodium borohydride (NaBH4) and Polyethyleneimine (PEI) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of Pt@SiO2@PABI-Tb Mesoporous SiO2 nanoparticles were prepared with the reported literature [20]. N-(4-benzoic acid-yl), N’-(propyltriethoxysilyl) urea (PABI) was prepared with the reported literature [21]. It was confirmed by 1H NMR as follows: 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) d(ppm), 12.51 (1H, bs, COOH), 8.81 (1H, s, NH), 7.80 (2H, d, ArH, J=8.0 Hz), 7.48 (2H, d, ArH, J = 8.7 Hz), 6.33 (1H, t, NH, J = 5.6 Hz), 3.75 (6H, q, OCH2 J = 7.0 Hz), 3.07 (2H, q, NCH2, J = 6.6 Hz), 1.48 (2H, CH2, quint, J = 8.0 Hz), 1.15 (9H, t, CH3(OEt), J = 7.0 Hz), 0.56 (2H, t, SiCH2, J = 6.8 Hz). 1.2 g of SiO2 nanoparticles were dispersed in 40 ml of KCl solution (0.1 M). 0.12 g of PEI solution was added in above solution and pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with diluted HCl. After 24 h of stirring, the suspension was separated by centrifugation and washed for 3 times. 4.8 ml of H2PtCl6·6H2O (10 mg/ml) solution were added in above SiO2 suspension and immersed for 12 h in dark. 5 ml of NaBH4 solution was added in the suspension with vigorous agitation. After 3 h, the grey-black particles were centrifuged and washed for three times. After vacuum drying, 0.6 g of SiO2@Pt (1.5 wt. % Pt) and 50 ml of DMF were settled in three necked flask. 10 ml of solution of PABI in DMF (0.03 g/ml) was added to above suspension under a N2 protection. Then the mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The suspension was centrifuged and washed with deionized water. The production SiO2@Pt@PABI was dispersed in 50 ml of water. 70 mg of TbCl3 was dissolved in 10 ml of water/ethanol mixture solution (2:3) and added into SiO2@Pt@PABI suspension. After the mixture was stirred for 12 h, the obtained SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb was centrifuged and washed with deionized water. 2.3 Preparation of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM PNIPAM decorated with PEI was prepared with our literature [22]. 0.3 g of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb was dispersed in 20 ml of water and mixed with 70 ml of PNIPAM/PEI (0.9 g). After the mixture was stirred for 48 h, the hydrogel was separated by centrifugation and washed with water for three times. Finally, SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM was dispersed in deionized water for further measure and experiment. 2.4 The catalytic activity The catalytic activity of composites was determined by measuring the rate of hydrogen generation. In the catalytic experiment, the flask was placed in constant temperature bath to maintain the reaction temperature (25 or 35 °C), and a gas burette filled with water was connected to the reaction flask in order to measure the volume of evolved hydrogen. 20 ml of suspension containing catalyst (SiO2@Pt, SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb or SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM) was added into 30 ml of aqueous solution. When 20 ml of AB (32.5 mg) solution was added into reaction flask containing catalyst, the volume of hydrogen was measured by recording the displacement of water level at a certain time interval. 2.5 Reusability of catalyst After the first catalytic reaction finished, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water. The catalyst was used in dehydrogenation of ammonia borane again. The same catalytic tests for the hydrolysis of AB were repeated five times. 2.6 Characterization Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Nicolet Nexus 470 FT/IR ranging from 500 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1. 1H NMR spectrum was obtained on a Bruker Avance III HD 400 MHZ instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a STA409 PC Luxx analyzer under an atmosphere of nitrogen. UV–vis spectra were recorded with a UV-1901. The electronic states of the catalyst were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi). A dynamic light scattering (DLS) were recorded with a ZEN 3690 laser light scattering spectrometer. The morphology and structures of particles were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL 6700-F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100). Emission spectra and lifetime of luminescent materials were obtained on a luminescence spectrometer (Edinburgh, FLS 1000) with a xenon lamp as the excitation source. The content of Pt in catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES-730). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of composites FT-IR spectra were used to identify the successful fabrication of composites. Fig. 1 shows the FTIR spectra of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM particles. The strong absorption peaks at 960, 803 and 1100 cm−1 are observed in two samples, which are attributed to the absorption bands of SiOH bending and SiOSi stretching, respectively. The appearance of characteristic peaks indicates that the inorganic silica is encapsulated in the hybrid catalysts. SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb shows the obvious characteristic peaks of organic materials. A brand band at 3450 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of OH and NH. The peaks at 1640, 1548 and 1384 cm−1 are assigned to stretching vibration CO, asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of COO- in PABI-Tb, respectively [21]. The characteristic stretching vibrations of PABI indicate that PABI-Tb complex is grafted on the SiO2 particles. For SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM, the characteristic peaks of CO and amide NH stretching in PNIPAM could overlap with some vibrations of PABI-Tb. However, the new peaks at 1460 cm−1 (CH3 and CH2- deformation), 2930 cm−1 (asymmetric stretching of CH2 ) and 2970 cm−1 (asymmetric stretching of CH3) are attributed to the CH3 and CH2 groups in PNIPAM. The characteristic vibrations of polymer indicate that the PNIPAM is integrated with SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb particles. Fig. 2 shows the TGA curves of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM, which indicate the mass loss of different components during heating process under a nitrogen atmosphere. For SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb, the mass loss below 110 °C is due to the removal of adsorbed water. Another mass loss occurs between 200 and 500 °C, which is credited to the degradation of PABI. The second mass loss indicates that about 2.5 % wt. PABI-Tb complex is grafted on the SiO2@Pt composites. For SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM, thermograms display two main stages of weight loss. The first stage exhibits approximately 8 % mass loss from 30 to 110 °C, which is credited to evaporation of water. The second step exhibits about 28 % mass loss between 200 and 550 °C, which is corresponded to the decomposition of polymer PNIPAM and organic component PABI. Finally, the sidual mass is about 62.5 %. The sidual component could be thermally resistant inorganic component silica because it could not degrade in experimental range. Thermo-sensitivities of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM hydrogels were investigated by DLS. The hydrodynamic diameters of composite particles vs. temperature are shown in Fig. 3 . The nanoparticles show the stable hydrodynamic sizes below 32 °C. However, the sizes of hydrogels increase sharply when external temperature exceed 32 °C. After 34 °C, the hydrogels show much lager hydrodynamic diameters than those at room temperature. The above results indicate that the composite hydrogels show the obvious thermo-sensitivities. Due to the presence of functional polymer, thermo-sensitive properties of composites should be provided by polymer PNIPAM. It is well known that PNIPAM is a thermo-responsive hydrogel and its lower critical solution temperature (LCST) is 32 °C. Below LCST, the chains of polymer are surrounded with water molecules and hydrogen-bonds could form between hydrophilic groups and water. The long chains could stretch into aqueous solution and the hydrogel is hydrophilic [17]. Therefore, the SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM hydrogel shows the stable hydrodynamic diameters below LCST. At the higher temperatures (>LCST), the polymer begin to dehydrate and shrink, and form a hydrophobic structure. The collapsed polymers could result in the aggregation of spherical particles, and the lager hydrodynamic sizes are observed in DLS. Fig. 4 shows the UV–vis spectra of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM hydrogel at different temperatures. At room temperature, it exhibits one intense band at 270 nm which is assigned to the π-π* transition of the conjugated double bonds in PABI-Tb [21]. However, the broad band almost disappears in the solution at 35 °C. The inserted photo shows the changes in the transparency of hydrogels at two temperatures. At 25 °C, the hydrogels is homogeneous. At higher temperature, the hydrogels begin to phase separation and the aggregation of composites appears at the bottom. The decrease of composites in supernatant could lead to the disappearance of characteristic broad band. UV–vis spectra indicate that SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM hydrogel displays a perfect swelling/shrinking behavior. XPS was used to characterize the electronic states of metal Pt in SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM. Fig. 5 (A, B) shows the deconvolution of Pt 4f bands, respectively. For SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb, two pairs of peaks appear at 71.7, 75.0, 72.8 and 75.9 eV. For SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM, two pairs of asymmetric peaks at 71.9, 75.3, 73.0 and 76.1 eV are ascribed to Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2, respectively. These peaks indicate the presence of metallic Pt (0) in composites. Fig. 6 (a, b) show the SEM pictures of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM. The SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb particles have the spherical morphologies with the uniform size of approximate 80 nm. SEM image of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM reveals that the composites consist of the polymer-encapsulated particles and many spherical particles are packed together due to the coating of PNIPAM. TEM pictures further verify the morphology and structure of composite catalysts. As shown in Fig.7 a, SiO2@Pt particles display the regular spherical shape with the size of around 80 nm, in good agreement with the observation in SEM pictures. Some black dots are clearly found in spherical silica particles, indicating that Pt nanoparticles are grafted in mesoporous silica. Fig.7b shows the TEM picture of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb particles. No obvious changes could be observed compared with SiO2@Pt particles, which show that PABI-Tb could be uniformly grafted on the surface of silica. The TEM images of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM shown in Fig. 7(c and d) clearly reveal that SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb particles are encapsulated in light gray PNIPAM. 3.2 Thermo-sensitive and switchable luminescence Fig. 8 shows the emission spectra of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM hydrogel at 25 and 35 °C. When the hydrogel is excited at 290 nm, it exhibits very strong green luminescence at 25 °C. The intensive characteristic emission peaks appear at 489, 544, 583 and 621 nm, which are assigned to the transitions from the 5D4 excited state to the ground states 7FJ (J = 6-3) of Tb3+, respectively. The most prominent peak is the green emission at 544 nm, corresponding to the hypersensitive transition of 5D4→ 7F5. In comparison, the characteristic emission peaks of hydrogel are much weaker at 35 °C. As shown in Fig. 8, the photo of luminescent hydrogels clearly exhibits the “on–off” luminescence at different temperatures. At room temperature, the high intensity green emission under UV irradiation could be clearly observed by eyes. However, the green luminescence almost disappears in the solution at 35 °C. The switchable luminescence is related with the deswell/swell structure of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM. Below LCST, the long chains of polymer could stretch into water and hydrogels are hydrophilic. As a result, the homogeneous hydrogels exhibit excellent green luminescence. Above LCST, the composites could separate from solution due to the hydrophobic interaction of polymer. The decrease of luminescent composite in supernatant results in the significant decrease of green luminescence. Luminescence decay curve of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM was obtained by monitoring 5D4→ 7F5 transition at 544 nm, which is shown in Fig. 9 . The data are fitted with a single exponential decay function and the luminescence lifetime is about 0.82 ms. 3.3 Thermo-responsive switchable catalytic activity As expected, the composite catalysts display the excellent catalytic performance towards the dehydrogenation of AB. The catalytic activities of SiO2@Pt, SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (Pt in catalysts: 1.15 × 10−5 mol) are shown in Fig. 10 (A and B). For SiO2@Pt, 70 ml of hydrogen could be released in 4.8 and 1.2 min at 25 and 35 °C, respectively. For SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb, AB could be hydrolyzed in 7.5 min with H2 volume of 70 ml at 25 °C. By contrast, the reaction time shortens to 1.75 min at 35 °C. The luminescent PABI-Tb has some effect on the catalytic activity of catalyst. The following is the possible reason for the different activities. As shown in TGA (Fig. 2), some amount of PABI-Tb (2.5 wt %) was grafted on the silica nanoparticles. The structure of organic/inorganic PABI-Tb was investigated in the reported literature [21]. The grafted PABI-Tb on silica nanoparticles could cause the steric hindrance for Pt nanoparticles. The steric hindrance of PABI-Tb could affect the approach of AB molecule to active Pt nanoparticles. Therefore, the SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb shows somewhat lower catalytic activity than SiO2@Pt. We calculated the turnover frequency (TOF) values (mol H2·  min-1·mol metal-1) for evaluating the catalytic activity of catalysts. TOF values were calculated by the following formula: TOF = n (H2)/ (n (Pt) × t). In the formula, n is mole number and t is reaction time (min). The TOF values of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb are determined as about 36.2 and 155.3 min-1 for 25 and 35 °C, respectively. The high catalytic activity of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb could be ascribed to the encapsulation of active Pt nanoparticles in silica nanoparticles. Most interestingly, SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM exhibits quite different catalytic performance in the dehydrogenation of AB at high temperature, in comparison to SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb. According to the time course of the hydrogen generation, 70 ml of hydrogen could be released in 9.2 min in the presence of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM at 25 °C. At room temperature, SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM shows a little lower catalytic activity than SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb due to the coating of polymer. At 35 °C, the reaction time greatly increases to 55 min and the TOF value drastically decreases to 4.9 min-1. The catalytic results indicate that the reaction rate significantly decreases in the presence of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM at high temperatures. The catalyst seems to exhibit a switchable catalytic performance at various temperatures. The distinct difference in catalytic activity could be ascribed to the thermo-sensitive behavior of PNIPAM. Fig. 11 shows the schematic illustration of catalysts at different temperatures and TEM picture of sample prepared at 35 °C. At 25 °C (below LCST), the composite hydrogel is hydrophilic and the chains of PNIPAM adopt an extended conformation. Therefore, AB molecule could approach the active Pt nanoparticles freely, and it exhibits high catalytic activity. At 35 °C (above LCST), the composites transform into a more hydrophobic structure due to the increase in polymer-polymer interaction. The long chains of polymer become collapse and shrink. The SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb spheres are coiled by collapsed packing polymers and the spherical particles could aggregate, which could effectively keep the active Pt nanoparticles from AB molecule. Reusability experiments are carried out because the durability of a catalyst is of importance for its practical applications. Fig. 12 shows the volume of hydrogen versus reaction time in 5th catalytic experiment at room temperature. It is noteworthy that no obvious decrease in catalytic activity could be observed after 5 cycles of catalysis. The catalysts exhibit the excellent durability and recycle stability because silica and PNIPAM layers could effectively prevent the aggregation and leaching of Pt nanoparticles during catalysis. Fig. 13 (a, b) show the TEM pictures of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb (a) and SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM (b) after reusability experiments. No aggregation of Pt nanoparticles could be found in the image and Pt nanoparticles with small sizes are still immobilizated in the MS particles. The SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb particles are still encapsulated in the PNIPAM. 4 Conclusions In summary, a temperature-responsive and luminescent catalyst of SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM was successfully prepared. The as-synthesized catalyst exhibits excellent “on-off” green luminescence and switchable catalytic performance. It shows excellent catalytic activity for hydrogen generation from AB at room temperature. However, the catalytic reaction rate for hydrogen generation drastically decreases at high temperature. Moreover, the catalyst shows an excellent durability for dehydrogenation of AB. The thermo-controllable catalytic performance and excellent reusability indicate that SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM is a promising smart catalyst for the practical application in the hydrogen generation from AB. CRediT authorship contribution statement Hui Huang: Writing - original draft, Investigation. Jun Wang: Supervision, Conceptualization, Writing - review & editing. Yafei Xu: Investigation. Rui Xu: Investigation. Wuke Li: Data curation. Declaration of Competing Interest There are no conflicts to declare. Acknowledgments This work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (number 21571074), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (CCNU19TS013) and 111 Project B17019. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a luminescent and thermo-responsive catalyst based on SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM was prepared by incorporating Pt nanoparticles, luminescent material and mesoporous silica with thermo-responsive polymer. The obtained catalyst was characterized by IR, TGA, UV–vis, SEM, TEM, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and luminescence. The hybrid catalyst exhibits “on-off” green luminescence in solution under UV irradiation, which could be observed by eyes. The catalytic results indicate that the dehydrogenation of ammonia borane (AB) catalyzed by SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM is thermo-controllable and switchable. The SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM shows high catalytic activity for the generation of hydrogen at room temperature. However, it exhibits much lower catalytic activity at high temperature. The catalysts exhibit excellent durability because the support and polymer could prevent the aggregation and leaching of Pt nanoparticles during catalysis. The catalytic research offers a new approach to the thermo-controllable application in the generation of hydrogen from AB.
coredata.dc:title: Thermo-controllable dehydrogenation of ammonia borane by luminescent and thermo-responsive catalysts based on SiO2@Pt@PABI-Tb@PNIPAM
